Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Understanding Robustness of Cellular Organization in Escherichia Coli through Nanofabricated Environments

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project explores the robustness of cellular organization, specifically the chromosome and the cell division apparatus of the bacterium E. coli. Engineered micro-fabricated and nano-fabricated environments will be used to physically constrain cells and control their chemical environment. Techniques of fluorescence and super-resolution microscopy, combined with quantitative image analysis, will be used to study local and macro-domain level organization of chromosomes, and the assembly of cell division proteins in a variety of constrained cell shapes and chemical environments. These studies will advance our understanding of the mechanisms that maintain cellular organization and their underlying robustness.

Broader Impacts. In addition to advancing design principles for nanofabrication, this project will provide training opportunities for graduate, undergraduate and high school students. This project will also engage undergraduate students who aim to become teachers of STEM disciplines in scientific research, and it will provide research experiences for students from under-represented groups through the Tennessee Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation program.

This award is co-funded by the Programs in Cellular Dynamics and Function and the Physics of Living Systems

POR.DRECONTENT:
The proposal addressed question of how 1) bacterial cell division apparatus and 2) chromosomes robustly self-organize into functional organelle-like entities within the cell, and how 3) chromosomes and cell division apparatus are physically linked together.  Our work employed high and super-resolution microscopy, microfluidic chips and modelling to study these questions in Escherichia coli bacteria. The results from these three areas of research are following:

1) Assembly of bacterial cell division apparatus. The assembly starts with formation of a ring-like structure, the Z-ring, at the middle of the rod-shaped cell. This assembly consists of FtsZ protein filaments, which are attached to the inner membrane by linker proteins. We investigated what leads to formation of this structure. Our data show that prior to the formation of the Z-ring, cross-linked FtsZ protein filaments accumulate transiently at random locations at the inner membrane with lifetimes from second to tens of seconds. We also found that assemblies compete for available FtsZ monomer pool in the cytosol. Our data indicate that the Z-ring formation occurs when one assembly is able to outcompete others. We also showed that in slower growth rates FtsZ limitation is result of ClpPX protease activity.  Degradation of FtsZ occurs when it dissociates from the Z-ring. The degraded amount accounts about 50% of FtsZ synthesized in each cell cycle.

2) Organization of bacterial chromosomes to nucleoid. Although bacterial chromosomes are not surrounded by membranes, they nevertheless form compact structures within the cell. The linear dimensions of these structures are about 1000-fold smaller than that of the DNA. Applying osmotic shocks and by squeezing cells in a microfluidic devices we determined that main factor causing compaction of the nucleoids are the macromolecular crowders. The crowers act on nucleoid via osmotic pressure. Our measurements showed that DNA respond to this osmotic pressure as a non-linear spring which stiffens at higher pressures. We found the experimentally determined compaction curves to be in good agreement with our coarse-grained modelling results. We furthermore found that protein crowders have a dominant contribution to the osmotic pressure at slow and poly-ribosome based crowders at faster growth rates.   

3) Physical link between cell division machinery and chromosomes. We found that the replication terminus region of the chromosome acts as landmark for assembly of cell division proteins in E. coli. In this positioning mechanism, which we referred to as the Ter linkage, three proteins (MatP, ZapB, ZapA) attach one after another to the replication terminus region of the chromosome. This macromolecular structure stabilizes membrane attached dynamic FtsZ filaments at its vicinity; possibly by cross-linking them via ZapA. Altogether this mechanism guarantees faithful positioning of cell division plane relative to chromosomes. We furthermore showed that when the positioning of cell division plane fails due to genetic perturbations then extra safeguarding is provided by a molecular pump consisting of FtsK.  Our measurements showed that FtsK can pump DNA rapidly between daughter compartments (1500 basepairs/second) and it is capable of moving persistently up to several megabases DNA. In most cells this movement occurs when the division septum is closed to a narrow pore of less than 200 nm in diameter.

In addition to these scientific findings large portion of our work was directed towards development of new microfluidic systems for studies of bacterial cells. This included development of agarose based microfluidics and development of so-called microanvil devices, which allowed to squeeze a micron-scale region of the bacterial cell. Using the latter device it was possible to divide an E. coli cell into two chemically uncoupled compartments. The results from the development work were published in two technical papers and in methods and supporting information sections of our papers.

Broader outreach. 1) From 2014-2019 the PI and members of his laboratory supervised teams of VolsTeach students in their semester-long Research Methods course. University of Tennessee (UTK) VolsTeach program is for undergraduate math, science, and engineering majors who want to pursue careers in K12 teaching. Students will acquire a teaching licensure at the end of their four-year program.   Each year one or two teams of students with three students per team carried out experiments, data analysis and modelling related to organization of bacterial chromosomes or the Z-ring. Some groups were also involved in constructing bacterial strains. 2) The PI lab hosted additional 15 undergraduate researcher, not related to VolsTeach Program, during 2104-2019 period. Of those 4 were REU students from under-represented minority groups recruited via TLSAMP program. 3) The PI gave lab tours in yearly bases to different groups of students. These included students from Governor School (high school students from the state of Tennessee) and UTK undergraduate Physics students. In the latter case the lab tour was preceded by one hour classroom presentation on modern microscopy techniques.
